examples.title: Countability of $\mathbb{Q}$
examples.statement: Show that the rational numbers are countable.

steps.title: Arrange in a grid
steps.content: List all $p/q$ with $p \in \mathbb{Z}$, $q \in \mathbb{N}^+$ in a 2D array.

solution.conclusion: $\mathbb{Q}$ is countable as a countable union of countable sets.

exercises.statement: Prove that the countable union of countable sets is countable.

steps.title: Label the sets
steps.content: Let $A_1, A_2, A_3, \ldots$ be countable sets with $A_n = \{a_{n,1}, a_{n,2}, \ldots\}$.

steps.title: Arrange in a grid
steps.content: Row $n$ contains elements of $A_n$. Enumerate diagonally.

exercises.statement: Use Cantor's diagonal argument to show that $\mathbb{R}$ is uncountable.

steps.title: Assume countable
steps.content: Suppose $\mathbb{R}$ (or $(0,1)$) can be listed as $r_1, r_2, r_3, \ldots$ with decimal expansions.

steps.title: Construct anti-diagonal
steps.content: Define $d$ by: the $n$-th digit of $d$ differs from the $n$-th digit of $r_n$.

steps.title: Contradiction
steps.content: $d$ differs from every $r_n$ in at least one digit, so $d \notin \{r_1, r_2, \ldots\}$.

solution.conclusion: No enumeration can list all reals; $\mathbb{R}$ is uncountable.
